nodes.text: Cross-country differences in average per capita GDP growth (1960-1985) are systematically related to initial human capital, initial per capita GDP, investment, fertility, government policy, political stability, and price distortions

Empirical strategy: cross-sectional regressions for 98 countries relating average annual growth rates of real per capita GDP to 1960 initial conditions and policy variables, using heteroskedasticity-consistent standard errors and alternative weightings
Proxy for human capital: school-enrollment rates (primary PRIM60 and secondary SEC60) measured in 1960, with supplementary measures including student-teacher ratios and adult literacy
Neoclassical prediction (context): per capita growth tends to be inversely related to initial per capita GDP (convergence) because of diminishing returns to reproducible capital
Conditional convergence claim: holding initial human capital and other controls constant, higher initial per capita GDP is strongly negatively associated with subsequent per capita growth

Human capital effect claim: greater initial human capital (higher SEC60 and PRIM60) is strongly positively associated with subsequent per capita growth, and explains part of the apparent lack of unconditional convergence

Investment and fertility links: higher initial human capital is associated with higher physical investment ratios and lower net fertility, and investment is positively associated with growth while net fertility is negatively associated with growth

Government consumption effect: higher ratios of government consumption to GDP (gc/y, excluding education and defense) are negatively associated with private investment and per capita growth; public investment shows little robust positive association with growth

Political instability claim: measures of instability (revolutions, coups, political assassinations) are negatively associated with investment and growth, plausibly via adverse effects on property rights

Price-distortion claim: deviations in purchasing-power-parity for investment deflators (PPPI deviation) are negatively associated with investment ratios and with growth; sign of deviation matters less than magnitude

Data sources and sample: primary data from Summers and Heston (1988), United Nations, World Bank, Banks (1979); main sample N=98 countries for 1960-1985, with some subsamples (76 countries) for public investment measures

Key regression evidence: regression 1 shows GDP60 coefficient about -0.0075 (per $1,000) and SEC60/PRIM60 positive and significant (partial correlations: GDP60 -0.74 conditional; human-capital proxy partial correlation 0.73); investment coefficient positive in growth regressions; gc/y negative; PPPI deviation negative; residual correlations between growth and investment positive (0.32-0.40) and growth and fertility negative (-0.26)

Measurement and proxy issues: 1960 enrollment rates may proxy for flows rather than stocks of human capital; 1950 enrollment data are noisy; GDP measurement error would need to be persistent to explain results; PPP and investment deflators may have measurement issues

Regional unexplained effects: dummy for sub-Saharan Africa and for Latin America remain significant negative influences on growth even after controlling for human capital, investment, fertility, government consumption, instability, and PPP deviations, indicating omitted factors

Overall conclusion: cross-country evidence supports a modified convergence viewâ€”poor countries grow faster than rich ones conditional on human capital; human capital raises investment and lowers fertility; government consumption, political instability, and measured price distortions are associated with lower investment and growth; substantial unexplained negative effects remain for Africa and Latin America and measurement/proxy limitations warrant further research
